title: Inconsistent use of parentheses for function/method references in documentation

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

body:
I'm noticing that, as titled, there are inconsistencies here and there within the `std` documentation (and core, alloc, etc) as to whether or not parentheses are used in references to methods and functions. Additionally there are even some method references that start with a fullstop.

I do not know what the policy is, but it appears (without thorough checks) to be so that the majority of references do _not_ use them. I'm not sure which way is best, but there should certainly be consistency.

I'm doing a little work to try to fix those that I can find and will submit a PR shortly.

I'm afraid that I can only afford to spend a little time right now removing parentheses from the handful of instances that use them. If a consensus were to develop that having them everywhere were more clear, that would have to be tackled separately later, by others if I cannot later find time for it.
